        console.log(obj);
        return obj + "X";
    },
    waitLogic: true
};

for (var o = 0; o < 2; o++) {
    jxcore.tasks.addTask(task, o + " Hello", function (res) {
        console.log("END", res);
    });
}

methods.name: forceGC
methods.desc: Forces garbage collection on V8 heap. Please use it with caution. It may trigger the garbage collection process immediately, which may freeze the application for a while and stop taking the requests during this time.

methods.name: getThreadCount
methods.desc: Returns the number of subthreads currently used by application (size of the thread pool).

methods.name: jobCount
methods.desc: Returns number of tasks currently waiting in the queue.

methods.name: killThread
methods.desc:
Kills a thread with given thread ID. This can be used for controlling the execution time of the task.

In example below, when the task starts it notifies the main thread about that fact. From that moment the main thread may start counting the timeout for killing the thread. 

// main thread receives the message from a task
jxcore.tasks.on("message", function(threadId, obj){
    if(obj.started){
        //kill the task after a second
        setTimeout(function(){
            jxcore.tasks.killThread(threadId);
            console.log("thread killed", threadId);
        },1000);
    }
});

// adding a task
jxcore.tasks.addTask( function() {
    // informing the main thread, that task is just started
    process.sendToMain({started:true});

    // looping forever
    while(true){};
    console.log("this line will never happen.");
});

methods.name: runOnce

params.textRaw: `method` {Function} - This is the method, which will be executed once for every existing subthread (getThreadCount() times).
params.name: method
params.desc: This is the method, which will be executed once for every existing subthread (getThreadCount() times).

methods.desc:
Adds new task (the method function with optional param argument) to be processed just once for every existing subthread. In other words, every subthread will call the task once. You can get number of subthreads by calling getThreadCount() method. Every subthread will process its task as soon as possible. If there are no other tasks in the subthreads queue, the task will be executed immediately. Otherwise it may wait until the other tasks in this subthread will finish.

If you don't want the method definition to be remembered by future threads use doNotRemember. It's false by default.

Running tasks with runOnce() method will also get emptyQueue event fired.

One of the cases for using runOnce() could be setting up a http server on each thread. 

jxcore.tasks.runOnce( method, "some parameter");

If for some reason any of the threads will be recreated (for example

methods.name: setThreadCount
methods.desc:
Sets the number of subthreads that you want to have in the thread pool for the application.

Generally, there is no need to use this method as JXcore by default will create 2 subthreads. In some scenarios you may want to change this number, but if you do, you must call env.setThreadCount() before the first use of jxcore.tasks object. After that, any subsequent calls of this method will be simply ignored.

The minimum, and default value is 2. The maximum value is 63, but keep in mind, that this amount of subthreads may not always bring performance benefits. In the contrary in some cases may do even worse, depending on the task implementation, so make sure that you always do some proper testing. Setting value outside this range will raise an exception. 

jxcore.env.setThreadCount(5);
var tasks = jxcore.tasks;

// the call below will be ignored, since we have just referenced jxcore.tasks object
// and the thread pool is already created.
jxcore.env.setThreadCount(10)

methods.name: unloadThreads
methods.desc:
Marks all subthreads to be removed from the thread pool. If they are idle the method removes them immediately. Otherwise it waits, until they finish their last tasks and removes them afterwards.

@include jxcore-thread

methods.name: bignum
methods.desc:
Create a new bignum from n and a base. n can be a string, integer, or another bignum.

If you pass in a string you can set the base that string is encoded in.

methods.name: fromBuffer
methods.desc:
Create a new bignum from a Buffer.

The default options are: 

{
    endian : 'big',
    size : 1, // number of bytes in each word
}

Note that endian doesn't matter when size = 1. If you wish to reverse the entire buffer byte by byte, pass size: 'auto'.

methods.name: prime
methods.desc: Generate a probable prime of length bits. If safe is true, it will be a "safe" prime of the form p=2p'+1 where p' is also prime.

modules.name: .tostring(base=10)
modules.desc: Print out the bignum instance in the requested base as a string.

properties.desc:
For all of the instance methods below you can write either 

bignum.method(x, y, z)

or if x is a bignum instance`` 

x.method(y, z)

modules.name: .tonumber()
modules.desc: Turn a bignum into a Number. If the bignum is too big you'll lose precision or you'll get Infinity.

modules.name: .tobuffer(opts)
modules.desc:
Return a new Buffer with the data from the bignum.

The default options are: 

{
    endian : 'big',
    size : 1, // number of bytes in each word
}

Note that endian doesn't matter when size = 1. If you wish to reverse the entire buffer byte by byte, pass size: 'auto'.

modules.name: .add(n)
modules.desc: Return a new bignum containing the instance value plus n.

modules.name: .sub(n)
modules.desc: Return a new bignum containing the instance value minus n.

modules.name: .mul(n)
modules.desc: Return a new bignum containing the instance value multiplied by n.

modules.name: .div(n)
modules.desc: Return a new bignum containing the instance value integrally divided by n.

modules.name: .abs()
modules.desc: Return a new bignum with the absolute value of the instance.

modules.name: .neg()
modules.desc: Return a new bignum with the negative of the instance value.

modules.name: .cmp(n)
modules.desc: Compare the instance value to n. Return a positive integer if > n, a negative integer if < n, and 0 if == n.

modules.name: .gt(n)
modules.desc: Return a boolean: whether the instance value is greater than n (> n).

modules.name: .ge(n)
modules.desc: Return a boolean: whether the instance value is greater than or equal to n (>= n).

modules.name: .eq(n)
modules.desc: Return a boolean: whether the instance value is equal to n (== n).

modules.name: .lt(n)
modules.desc: Return a boolean: whether the instance value is less than n (< n).

modules.name: .le(n)
modules.desc: Return a boolean: whether the instance value is less than or equal to n (<= n).

modules.name: .and(n)
modules.desc: Return a new bignum with the instance value bitwise AND (&)-ed with n.

modules.name: .or(n)
modules.desc: Return a new bignum with the instance value bitwise inclusive-OR (|)-ed with n.

modules.name: .xor(n)
modules.desc: Return a new bignum with the instance value bitwise exclusive-OR (^)-ed with n.

modules.name: .mod(n)
modules.desc:
Return a new bignum with the instance value modulo n.

m.

modules.name: .pow(n)
modules.desc: Return a new bignum with the instance value raised to the nth power.

modules.name: .powm(n,_m)
modules.desc: Return a new bignum with the instance value raised to the nth power modulo m.

modules.name: .invertm(m)
modules.desc: Compute the multiplicative inverse modulo m.

modules.name: .rand()
modules.desc:
If upperBound is supplied, return a random bignum between the instance value and upperBound - 1, inclusive.

Otherwise, return a random bignum between 0 and the instance value - 1, inclusive.

modules.name: .rand(upperbound)
modules.desc:
If upperBound is supplied, return a random bignum between the instance value and upperBound - 1, inclusive.

Otherwise, return a random bignum between 0 and the instance value - 1, inclusive.

modules.name: .probprime()
modules.desc:
Return whether the bignum is:

  • certainly prime (true)
  • probably prime ('maybe')
  • certainly composite (false)

using BN_is_prime_ex.

modules.name: .sqrt()
modules.desc: Return a new bignum that is the square root. This truncates.

modules.name: .root(n)
modules.desc: Return a new bignum that is the nth root. This truncates.

modules.name: .shiftleft(n)
modules.desc: Return a new bignum that is the 2^n multiple. Equivalent of the << operator.

modules.name: .shiftright(n)
modules.desc: Return a new bignum of the value integer divided by 2^n. Equivalent of the >> operator.

modules.name: .gcd(n)
modules.desc: Return the greatest common divisor of the current bignum with n as a new bignum.

modules.name: .jacobi(n)
modules.desc:
Return the Jacobi symbol (or Legendre symbol if n is prime) of the current bignum (= a) over n. Note that n must be odd and >= 3. 0 <= a < n.

Returns -1 or 1 as an int (NOT a bignum). Throws an error on failure.

modules.name: .bitlength()
modules.desc: Return the number of bits used to represent the current bignum.
